awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Small: Towards Secure and Reliable Network Tomography in Wireline and Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Today's networks, such as the Internet, cellular networks, and the Internet of Things, provide ubiquitous wired or wireless connections over large areas. Secure and reliable operations are among the most important objectives in these networks. Network tomography has become a promising framework for accurate monitoring of network operation status, which is vital to ensure an efficient and reliable network environment. However, this measurement process can be exploited by malicious attackers to generate falsified, misleading measurement or monitoring results, which significantly affects follow-on network operations based on these results, and accordingly degrades the operational reliability and health of today's networks. The goal of this project is to analyze security vulnerabilities, understand potential security attack strategies and their impact, and design effective defense mechanisms against such attacks. The research in this project will extend the technical knowledge of security vulnerabilities, attacks and defense during network measurement. The project will also offer undergraduate students opportunities to gain research experiences in network measurement and security. 

The project focuses on investigating a new class of security attacks, called measurement integrity attacks, during the measurement process in network tomography. Unlike conventional data integrity problems that can be usually protected by standard security methods (e.g., encryption and authentication), a key challenge in measurement integrity attacks is that the network event data (e.g., packet transmission/delivery timings and loss) during measurement is not protected by standard security methods, but can be easily manipulated by an inside attacker. This project aims at (i) creating the theoretical foundation to analyze the feasibility and impact of measurement integrity attacks with different attack strategies in wireline and wireless scenarios, (ii) designing robust attack detection and localization methods, and analyzing the effectiveness of such countermeasures, (iii) investigating efficient management methods for network measurement to increase the attack resilience in a network, and (iv) conducting comprehensive evaluation of the efficiency and effectiveness of attack countermeasures in both wireline and wireless networks.

por.por_cntn:
The project is focused on investigating the security issues in network tomography or inference in wireline and wireless networks. The nature of the original design in network tomography or inference does not consider any security issue as it commonly assumes that there is no misbehaving node existing in a network. However, as the advancement of attack strategies, it is never guaranteed that a node cannot be compromised in a network, especially for nodes with less capability and security protection. However, such nodes can be actively involved in any network measurement process. A compromised node can lead to severe performance degradation of an inference strategy. The project aims at investigating the measurement integrity issues caused by any potential attacker via analytical modeling, mathematical formulation, comprehensive simulations, and experimental evaluations. In addition, the project also attempts to understand any related attack, corresponding defense and their applications in various scenarios for both wireline and wireless networks

The project considers three major attack scenarios in network tomography and inference: 1) the attack strategy in link status tomography, where an attack aims to choose a particular link victim as the scapegoat to launch the attack, maximize the total damage in the network, or obfuscate the overall results in link tomography; 2) the attack aiming to use flow tomography to determine the end-to-end connectivity relationship in a multi-hop network scenario; and 3) the attack that aims to leverage the network topology tomography by systematically transmitting probe packets going through a network to infer its internal topology. It is found that the maximum-damage attack is the most feasible attack strategy that also causes the worst damage in network link tomography. Obfuscation is generally more difficult to launch than the maximum-damage attack, but its feasibility increases when the attacker can affect more nodes or links under a particular routing protocol. Despite the potential severe impacts of link status tomography attacks, detection and localization methods have also been modeled, analyzed, and developed in the project. It is found that proactive routing mechanisms (i.e., intentionally introducing path randomness during packet routing) are able to cause significant errors observed by an attacker that aims to infer network connectivity relationship, thereby mitigating the attacker’s impact on end-to-end connectivity inference. The performance cost and security benefits have been carefully analyzed for different proactive routing templates. It is also found that network topology tomography leveraged by an attacker can be disrupted by a proactive network monitor system that first detects an attacker’s probe packets and then intentionally delays these packets such that the inferred network topology will become completely a random one.  Extensive simulations and evaluations have been carried out during the course of the project to validate the modeling and analysis results.

The project has resulted in publications in major academic conferences and journals. The research results have been widely disseminated at conferences, workshops, and seminars, and made available at the PI’s website. Educational materials have also been introduced in networking and security classes for both undergraduate and graduate programs at University of South Florida.
